channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Hidden passage of emperors opened at the Colosseum
item.description: Visitors to the Colosseum in Rome can now walk through a tunnel that even in Roman times was exclusively reserved for emperors
item.content:encoded: Visitors to the Colosseum in Rome can now walk through a tunnel that even in Roman times was exclusively reserved for emperors
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Author of 'The Second Estate' argues that America's tax code has created a new aristocracy
item.description: In her book The Second Estate, Ray Madoff explains how the U.S. tax system lets the ultra-rich grow their wealth tax-free while working Americans bear the burden.
item.content:encoded: In her book The Second Estate, Ray Madoff explains how the U.S. tax system lets the ultra-rich grow their wealth tax-free while working Americans bear the burden.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: The politics behind President Trump's plan to send troops to U.S. cities
item.description: President Trump and the GOP are hoping that sending troops to US cities will be a winning strategy for the midterm elections.
item.content:encoded: President Trump and the GOP are hoping that sending troops to US cities will be a winning strategy for the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: How the time change could help teens rest
item.description: The switch to standard time offers sleep-deprived teenagers a rare chance to catch up on much-needed rest.
item.content:encoded: The switch to standard time offers sleep-deprived teenagers a rare chance to catch up on much-needed rest.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Boden

item.title: How NPR reporters turn newspaper stories into sound
item.description: NPR's Laura Sullivan, Frank Langfitt and Sacha Pfeiffer reflect on how writing for radio differs from their days in newspapers, and what it takes to make stories come alive through sound.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Laura Sullivan, Frank Langfitt and Sacha Pfeiffer reflect on how writing for radio differs from their days in newspapers, and what it takes to make stories come alive through sound.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Can the Global South trust Starlink?
item.description: Elon Musk's satellite network Starlink is rapidly expanding across the Global South amid a lack of industry regulation. Steven Feldstein, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, explains what is at stake.
item.content:encoded: Elon Musk's satellite network Starlink is rapidly expanding across the Global South amid a lack of industry regulation. Steven Feldstein, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, explains what is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen

item.title: The shutdown leaves one in eight Americans unsure how they'll buy food
item.description: A halt in SNAP payments has millions worried about their next meal, raising new questions about how a program born in the Great Depression still defines America's fight against hunger.
item.content:encoded: A halt in SNAP payments has millions worried about their next meal, raising new questions about how a program born in the Great Depression still defines America's fight against hunger.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Ludden

item.title: A temporary calm in the U.S.-China trade war after Trump–Xi meeting
item.description: A highly-anticipated meeting between president Trump and Xi Jinping leads to a pause - but not an end - to trade and tech competition issues.
item.content:encoded: A highly-anticipated meeting between president Trump and Xi Jinping leads to a pause - but not an end - to trade and tech competition issues.
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: GOP Sen. Lisa Murkowski urges colleagues to reach deal as SNAP benefits dry up
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Sen. Lisa Murkowski about the possible loss of SNAP benefits due to the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Sen. Lisa Murkowski about the possible loss of SNAP benefits due to the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levitt

item.title: Disputed election result in Cameroon fuels tensions with younger generation
item.description: Driving through barricades and burned banks in Douala: Cameroon's disputed election sparks a showdown with its young generation.
item.content:encoded: Driving through barricades and burned banks in Douala: Cameroon's disputed election sparks a showdown with its young generation.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu
